now just as a little refresher of why

smm is system management mode and this
you can think of essentially as the
highest level of privilege some people
call it ring -2 and the way it works is
that there's a small region of memory
called the uh SM Ram that's inaccessible
to the operating system and it's
initialized by the bios so if you can
control the BIOS you can get code
running in that SM RAM and it's going to
be invisible to anything that's running
at the operating system level so it's a
really great place to Target if you want
to compromise a machine and have it be
invisible and have it not be uh

bios smm

that uh we haven't really come up with

systems that run today the expectation
is that the main memory is volatile when

gone and because of this people you know
treat that as trusted uh if you run a

any sort of data any crypto keys are all

to notice it but you could build a

people have discussed using fpgas or

to put a device in the system before
it's actually running with anything so
about 2008 there was a revelation about

they literally took a aerosol spray
which cost like five bucks and frees the
physical memory in a system and the
interesting prop here is that memory
will retain its contents for several
minutes so the picture of the laptop is
is their original shot uh we reproduce

something you can do on your own and you
can walk away with the contents of
memory no anecdotally I've had some

so C is a real you know practical way of

obviously disruptive in this case so
you're going to shut down a system and

notice so one concern is a technology
that's becoming more prevalent which is
nonvolatile RAM and the idea here is
this is the other picture I showed at
the beginning this has a super capacitor
actually attached to the memory and the
memory also has some flash storage like
you'd find in a camera or phone and the

it'll copy the cont and memory to that

so my attack here is that I get some

becoming like a disc and today it's

Ram is that there's several Technologies

so I would expect in the next 5 to 10

and with just all memory systems and not

Technologies out there that can help

there's some diagnostic tools available

it's not security specific but you know
is available and as open source uh Intel
chips SEC this is a pretty recent tool

now when it comes to the boot Integrity
attacks um one approach to mitigating it
is a verified Boot and some of the
terminology that's used I think you know
Microsoft uses the phrase secure boot uh
this is from a chromium diagram or
excuse me chrom OS diagram uh which they
call verified boot but the main idea is
that you've got some small trusted read
only memory and it's hard to see in this
picture but it's at the top of this
chain and that's got a key a public key
in there that can verify a signature on
the next chunk that's actually going to
load so you've got something rooted in
Hardware it's readon and it'll verify a
signature of the thing that loads next
the next block can't aim over there next
block down the chain will be verified by
the one previous the idea is that as you
go through this boot process every step
of the way is is verified by the
previous step so this is being used in
Chromebooks today I think more recent
version of Windows also have a similar
mechanism but it's actually a pretty
good mitigation for this so if somebody
comes in and changes one of these pieces
of firmware the signature verification
should fail and um you know you
shouldn't boot or it should give you
some warning now Chrome books actually
have a way of work around this to let
people run their own operating system
that may not have these These Chains so
you can disable this
check now another technology with
similar goals that works slightly
different is called trusted execution
technology or txt and in this picture
I've got all the firmware and software
that is required to boot up the system
and what's happening is this is going to
get measured by the CPU using uh kind of
a special state in instruction and the
CPU will take those measurements and put
them into registers on a trusted
platform module so a separate piece of
hardware and after boot time you might
have booted up something malicious uh
somebody else can connect to the syst
system and actually do a remote
attestation protocol directly with the
TPM and what they'll get out of this is
a signed manifest of everything that
booted on that system so what you're
seeing here in these columns that's a
little hard to read but the these are
the special registers on the TPM and
these are just hash values and on the
right I've kind of denoted what they are
so the BIOS authenticated code modules
measured launch environment kind of
everything that booted up with the
system now txt is not per it's got some
flaws so in the past there have been a
couple vulnerabilities uh the first
version of TPM 1.1 had a paperclip of

have also been some overflows in the s
in it which uh I think that was

several years ago um kind of currently
there are some risks as well so the the
Providence of the BIOS and the firmware
you don't really know what's good and
what's bad so you can measure it but who
tells you whether it's good or bad and
then the vendors haven't really supplied
that
information um there's a black hat talk

they demonstrate extracting keys from

and also that bus this is called an LPC

across so kind of hypothetical going

these authenticated code modules are

ation so a technology called immu This

IU when

you can keep your disc encrypted and
your memory is going to have the key
sitting in PL text memory it's exposed
so you can do a cold boot you can do a
dma attack unless you use IMU uh you can

called Crypt Keeper was the idea here is
you're going to encrypt most of memory
then keep the key in the little portion
that remains now this is kind of just
obscuring it because they don't really
deal with the issue of where the key is
they you know propose some ideas about
separate Hardware or offis skating it
but doesn't really solve the problem
somebody can get the key out but if you
have kind of a lazy attacker who's just
going to look for plain Tech strings it
might
help uh treasure this is an approach
that's a Linux kernel modification so
after all the cold boot cold boot stuff
came out uh the idea here is that you
can keep like an as key in the debug
registers for a CPU and they won't be
kept in main memory so if you do a cold
boot uh the key is kept in the CPU and
you can grab memory and you're not going
to be able to decrypt the dis so you
might get some contents of memory but
you're not going to get the full
contents of the disc and be able to
decrypt it
offline uh Frozen cache this is kind of
a different approach and their idea is
that if you've got a laptop and you want
a screen lock it you can put the key to
the dis and all the code to do the
unlock in the cache and freeze the cash
so if somebody comes in and takes the
memory out of the system it's not going
to have the dis encryption key in there
and once you type in your password that
code's in the cache it can you know
unlock the cache and then put the key
back in main memory so you'll be exposed
while you're using your laptop but while
it's screen locked or you're going
through you know the airport security uh
the key won't be in
memory Karma this is a paper out of CMU
and uh it's got a similar approach where
they actually just don't use main memory
and their observation is that these L3
caches the last level caches are getting
really big the latest Intel server CPUs
have ones that are 25 30 37 and a half
Megs and that's bigger than you know the
first hard drive I've ever had so it's
it's quite big and you can run a full
operating system in the L3 cache so they
run basically just a secure operating
system in the cache on the CPU no
dependency on Main memory now putting
together these ideas is something that I
I've been working on uh my company it's
called called the software crypto
processor so it's kind of a similar idea
to Karma where you keep the cash pinned
run an operating system in the cach keep
your key in the cache and then encrypt
access to main memory and the
technologies that made this possible are
the fact that CPUs today have support
for crypto in the instruction set they
have these huge L3 caches and they also
have random number generators at least
with Intel CPUs so you've got Randomness
you've got big space to work with and
the ability to do fast crypto and
somebody extracting the memory of the
system just gets plain text or excuse me
just gets Cipher
text so moving on to some upcoming
Technologies uh I want to talk about
these really quickly so these are
technologies that we expect to see in
the pipeline uh one is software based
adastation and this is actually being
used in some mobile contexts but the
idea is that you're going to have some
metrics that you're going to measure
from a system that's running and if the
good software is running it should have
predictable results if if somebody
changes it it should throw off those
metrics very bad now the challenge here
is you have to need to make sure you're
not being simulated in a VM so you know
if you've got a mobile device you got to
make sure you're not talking to a mobile
VM running on a powerful server and one
way to do this is with some keys rooted
in Hardware now one technology that
Intel has been talking about is called
EP ID which is enhanced privacy ID and
this is kind of a successor to direct
Anonymous atation which is is built into
the TPMS today and what it does provide
a CPU a way to anonymously sign data and
not reveal its own identity so it's like
a group signature saying you're a member
of a certain group but not which
individual and so this is could be a
very powerful tool and one thing that
it's useful for is the fact that you've
got some key material rooted in the CPU
so now CPUs can authenticate themselves
without leaking which ident which
specific CPU it is now that's also a
downside as that's rooted in this unique
key so one technology that uses this
epid key or similar key material is
called sgx or software guard extensions
and this was kind of quietly revealed
last summer by Intel and has been
blogged about a little bit but hasn't
gotten a lot of attention and what sgx
is is a new set of instructions that are
going to be coming out on the on future
generations of Intel processors probably
in the next two to three years and they
allow you to run a small secure Enclave
of user level code uh that's
inaccessible from other code in the
system even kernel level
code that Enclave is going to be backed
by encrypted memory that's encrypted by
Hardware so it's not going to be exposed
to these physical attacks and also not
going to be exposed to any other malware
running on the system based on this uh
protection that they're they're building
in the hardware uh enclaves are also
going to be attested so when you load
one up this Hardware key uh built in the
CPU is going to measure what's loaded
and be able to do that attestation
protocol with somebody else so you can
have enclaves attest each other and you
can also remotely or should be able to
remotely connect to an enclave and
attest it now the downside is that all
these pieces make it very useful for DRM
I can get my you know movie decrypting
code running in an enclave I can
provision a key to it once I've attested
it and you as the user may not be able
to look into there and see what's
happening so if you're trying to rip
DVDs or doing whatever the key for that
it may become very hard using this
technology so I'm coming to end of the

things I'd like to see to actually
improve the landscape out there so I
mentioned at the beginning that smm is
kind of a big hole and there's supposed
to be this notion of a smm transfer

usable so uh this is something I like to

else otherwise protect
yourself um sgx as I mentioned is going

know some unique key material for that

somebody might be able to identify my
